body:
Thanks for posting in our issue tracker.
In order to properly assist you, we need additional information:

- When does the issue occur?
- What do you see?
- What was the expected result?
- Can you supply us with a stacktrace? (optional)
- Do you have exact code to reproduce it? Maybe a PHPUnit tests that fails? (optional)

Thanks!

_This is an automated comment, triggered by adding the label `status:need more info`._

I'm not sure what I can add.

I had an existing MVC based on a table which worked fine using

`$model->save(false)`

After adding a RowVersion column (named it RV in this instance) to the table so I could use a Flow on it, it would no longer perform the create action reporting the error posted above.

I tried adding the column to the model and setting the attribute to NULL, that didn't work.
I tried setting the attribute value to DEFAULT via the model rules, but that didn't work.  The SQL showed it was set as DEFAULT, but still reported an error and wouldn't save (seemed to be an attribute ordering issue in the SQL Statement).
I tired, as shown above, to provide an attribute listing excluding the RV column, that didn't work.
I tried using a trigger to remove any RV value passed, that didn't work either.

So I had to resort to creating the INSERT SQL statement and executing it rather than using the model's save method.  Although this was 'working' it also resulted in tons of log errors that I couldn't figure out and finally reverted.

I can't seem to find much documentation on the subject, how to declare a RowVersion properly in a model.  Should it even be declared if it is to be omitted?

I've seen similar posts where they were told to DEFAULT the RowVersion column, but you can't do that.  It simply not possible and SSMS returns an error clearly stating that.

RowVersion is fundamental to MSSQL and should be a priority.  As for me, I am royally ... as I now have a broken app.
@darkdef could you help maybe? I'm not familiar with MSSQL unfortunately...
It's error. I will try to fix it
I'm pretty sure I did that already, but I will try again and post back.  It will take me a day or 2 though.  Thank you for the suggestion.
And please show me structure of you table (for model)

issue.title: #19520 - fix fow TIMESTAMP & ROWVERSION column in insert
